bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, October 16, 1940

div1.p: Hench describes valuable details on the yellow fever experiments he found in Agramonte's papers. Hench believes, along with Kean, that Agramonte has been treated unjustly.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, October 16, 1940
div1.p:
I am writing you this in a rather unusual fashion -
in pencil - as I am home & want a carbon of this note. Please
excuse it & I hope you can read it. I hasten to mail you the
last part of my W & J talk to be given just 10 days from now
I am so very anxious to have your approval of the manner
on what I quote you. There will be plenty of time to correct or
alter it before it is published in a Medical Journal but I have
been asked to have a copy ready for the Press as soon as
possible and want to be sure I have quoted you correctly
As you see I have given all you fed me (that is as much as
I deemed it proper to use) in quotation marks - not only to
let the audience & public understand clearly the source of
my information, that is to give you full & sole credit for
that part but also because that as much more interesting
to give it as a direct quotation & I do hope you approve,

I will send you the first 11 pages as soon as they have
been revised. Therein I give a running account of the
well known orthodox version - the formation of the Board,
the work at Columbia Barracks, Hospital, the Las Animas
work, the death of Lazear (official version) & then the work
at Camp Lazear. To condense that much in 11 pages
necessitated omitting much that I will eventually publish
(2-3-4 years from now ??) in more ample form. But I
was able to introduce all the characters involved, including
yourself! Naturally in such a short account as this &
under the special circumstances I have dealts more with
Lazear than the others and have therefore entitled this
particular paper “Dr Jesse W Lazear & his contribution to the
Conquest of Yellow Fever. In order not to be misunderstood
and to be accused of playing favorites by relatives of
C or A or by those who would favor Moran over Kissinger
or vice versa I have attached a footnote on the front
page as follows: on the occasion of the dedication
of a Lazear memorial the writer deems it appropriate
(2
to deal chiefly with the activities of Lazear but by so doing, it is
not the writer's intention to minimize in the slightest degree the
contribution of any of the several persons who participated in
the conquest of this disease. The writer proposes to deal
elsewhere & more fully with the whole story.”

If you approve of the way I have quoted you will you
please wire me collect right away - just say “Approved,”
or if you have any significant change Id appreciate it so
much if you'd airmail it to me special delivery so that
perhaps I can hear from you before Sunday or Monday
I leave for the east on Wed.

I know you will be interested in Miss Agramonte's
version. Perhaps you may criticize it where she
gives her father's analysis of the possible motive which
actuated Lazear to inoculate himself. And yet I,
an outsider, found this analysis very interesting & it
is obviously only an opinion which cannot in any way
harm Lazear's memory. I am aware of your contention
that A. seems to have written lots more than he had the
opportunity to know But Gen. Kean believes that he did
an injustice to A in parts of the Senate Document and
I hope I do not offend you or seen to show your opinion
any disrespect when I say that I believe Dr A must
have been more familiar with what was going on than
some believe. When I first tried to work out the calendar
(day to day & hour to hour) of the whole story I found many
gaps in the official versions & several down right
contradictions in dates & other data as given in the
various parts of the Senate Document & indeed Reed's
paper contain some contradictions. Later when I offered
Dr A's 1915 article I rejoiced for I (an outsider)
found some interest data there that explained some of the
contradictions & other data or dates & persons that
appeared nowhere else. Let me give one example.
3
In one of Reeds papers he speaks of 2 non immunes being on the
protected side of the mosquito Bldg. 1, later on he speaks of
3 non immunes entering that room, still later he reverts to
the figure two. Nobody was able to straighten me out on that
part & to show how confused others were Mrs Hallock who
wrote up the Metropolitan Life Ins. Co primer re Reed et
al couldn't straighten it out & on their film she put
2 persons, in another diagram she put 3. Well a
perusal of Agramonte's paper explains it. In fact
only 2 non-immunes stayed night after night in the
protected side of the mosquito room but on the first
day Reed himself as the other non-immune,
went on about the other two to see how things were
going. Only in A's paper is that recorded.

Another little point that makes me lend much
credence to A's paper. only his paper tells of the story that
the Spanish immigrants at Camp Lazear were allowed to
acclimate themselves & be studied in preliminary fashion
while being occupied in picking up stones at the Camp
A small detail - yes let accurate & to me it proved very
useful. When we visited Mrs Rojas & the San Jose farm
I wasnt too sure whether I could trust their “facts”, recalled
after 40 years. But one of the first things Mrs Rojas
told me was the incident of the stone - picking. She
had no knowledge that her farm had ever been called
Camp Lazear. She didnt at first ever recall Reed's
name. She knew nothing about the “false Camp Lazear”
& had never seen or heard of Agramonte's article nor
had I mentioned the stone - picking episode & yet she
told me that It was one of the things that made me know
She was telling the truth & now (did I tell you this)
they have found her husbands old day-book giving
(4
a detailed record of the transactions worked in renting
Camp Lazear from “Major Mr. Reed” & receiving checks
from Major Kean & Dr Echeverria. Also as a result
we found that the Bldgs 1 & 2 were NOT torn down but
were to become the property of its owner & as a further
result we have discovered what may in truth be the
remains of Bldg 1. - facing south & measuring
20 x 14 feet. I examined it curiously last spring on
the outside but it has been altered some & some
excesses added & it didnt look promising
& I couldn't quite reconcile it with the slope of the land
but further study of photos, Arpography, new photos
compared to old ones etc etc has made me very hopeful that
we have indeed found one of the silent witnesses of
great deeds. Unfortunately the Bldg # 2 was torn
down just 5 years ago!

Well I have digressed but I meant to indicate
why I have given much credence to A's remark &
to Miss A's version of them. She is a most charming
person, wonderfully cultured. You'd be delighted with her.
She let me see her fathers letters & papers & I found so
many evidences of (apparent?) humility that I could
not but be impressed.

(By the way our Bldg # 1 has “tongued & grooved
boards” too"!

My but I wish you could be write us next Saturday.
I do hope I may pay my respects to you in California
before another year passes. Your paper is GRAND &
MUST be published. I will write you some thoughts
on that when I got my health. Unfortunately I am
not only writing up this Y F stuff but the letter
(5
is a mere side issue which came at the time I am trying to
finish on Seventh Annual Rheumatism Review which I
edit yearly & write (90%) myself. It is due in 3
weeks & is 300 pages long!! Did I send you one of
last year? Would you like to receive the Proceedings
of the Mayo Clinic with my complements - no cost to
you?

Thank you so much for letting me keep the
memorandum a little longer. Dare I be bold
enough to make a wish? I am something of a
bibliophile & autograph fiend. I have a really nice
medical library - original copies of Waltering, Jenner,
Beaumont - not many but some. I also have a small
but nice collection of letters of Pasteur, Paget,
Addison, Lester etc etc. IF you revise the copy
of your mss & are about to throw it away (the copy
with your & Kean's Marginal notes) I would be
eternally grateful if you'd strive it my way that I
could add it to my own small yellow fever collection
I can assure you it will always be preserved. The
Mayo clinic library (Museum Section) has already
asked me for some of my data & I have promised
full access of my data (photostats of whatever they
want that is discrete) etc to the Univ. of Va. library
(my brother is Prof of English literature there), also to
the Welsh library & the Army Museum.

But enough of my terrible handwriting.
I would so appreciate your prompt comment
(approval or corrections) of my paper.
